text: Pakistan has recalled its High
Commissioner from India for
consultations this follows a sharp rise
in the diplomatic tension between the
two regional rivals after a suicide
attack on Indian troops in
indian-administered Kashmir India has
accused Pakistan of being behind the
bombing by Islamist militants in a
further escalation at least four Indian
soldiers were killed in a gunfight with
rebels fighting broke out as a security
forces search for Islamist militants
thought to be linked to the bombing
India recalled its top diplomat from
Islamabad last week for talks following
developments for the BBC is our
correspondent in Islamabad from Mali and
in Delhi
thank you to my scare she gave me the
response of the Indian government since
Thursday's attack India's Prime Minister
Narendra Modi has come out strongly
calling the crime heinous calling it
dastardly calling those that died
martyrs he has said now on at least
three separate occasions that those
behind this attack
will face retribution of some kind as
you say the Indians now claiming that
they have incontrovertible evidence that
Pakistan backed militants carried out
this attack this attack which happened
on Thursday involved a suicide bomber
driving an SUV packed full of explosives
into a troop convoy that led what we now
believe is 46 deaths as a result last
Friday India withdrew its High
Commissioner from Islamabad saying that
it wanted to consult on matters arising
from this terrorist atrocity and then
today we have the Pakistanis saying that
their High Commission the Commissioner
to Delhi will now be recalled back to
Pakistan again to consult on the ongoing
situation it's worth also noting that
economic sanctions are being put in
place Arun Jaitley who's the finance
minister here in India on Thursday
announced that he would be taking
measures and over the course of the
weekend what we saw was a 200% tax being
slapped on imported goods from Pakistan
the hope there quite clearly is
that this will either slowed down trade
from Pakistan or just stop it altogether
okay so Secunda now I just want to get
the reaction to all this in Pakistan
well in Pakistan the reaction has been
much more muted than it's been across
the border Pakistani officials have
really focused on making two main points
one denying that Pakistan was in any way
involved in last week's attack and
pointing out that the the suicide bomber
was apparently a local from
indian-administered Kashmir rather than
a Pakistani citizen and secondly
Pakistani officials have highlighted
allegations of human rights abuses by
Indian security forces in
indian-administered Kashmir and have
suggested that those abuses are
fundamentally the cause the root cause
behind the ongoing unrest and violence
in the region when it comes to this
group that has claimed responsibility
for this attack joshi mohammed it is a
group that is officially banned in
Pakistan has been banned for a number of
years however its its leader despite
being in what's known as protective
custody is still able to give weekly
audio messages that are released in the
groups magazine online and and the group
is thought to have or have had in the
past certainly strong links to
Pakistan's intelligence services what's
confusing analysts a little bit on this
occasion is that in the past when we've
seen these kind of militant attacks by
militarized to have links to the
Pakistani security forces it's been
thought that these are attempts by the
Pakistani security services to prevent
the civilian government becoming too
close to India and and and reaching
potentially some kind of more peaceful
relationship but actually at the moment
both the military and the government of
Imran Khan prime minister Imran Khan
seem to be on the same page in wanting a
better relationship with India when
Imran Khan was elected last year he said
that for every step India took to his
barkas
Pakistan would take - towards India but
clearly incidents like this will make it
much harder to normalize relations
between the two countries
so come - come on either
